knowledges.speaker: Phoebe

synsets.definition: cause to open or to become open
_examples: Mary opened the car door

synsets.definition: start to operate or function or cause to start operating or functioning
_examples: open a business

synsets.definition: become open
_examples: The door opened

synsets.definition: begin or set in action, of meetings, speeches, recitals, etc.
_examples: He opened the meeting with a long speech

synsets.definition: spread out or open from a closed or folded state
_examples: open the map
spread your arms

synsets.definition: make available
_examples: This opens up new possibilities

synsets.definition: become available
_examples: an opportunity opened up

synsets.definition: have an opening or passage or outlet
_examples: The bedrooms open into the hall

synsets.definition: make the opening move
_examples: Kasparov opened with a standard opening

synsets.definition: afford access to
_examples: the door opens to the patio
The French doors give onto a terrace

synsets.definition: display the contents of a file or start an application as on a computer

knowledges.origin_sent: I know, I opened it up and there it was, just floating in there, like this tiny little hitch - hiker!

knowledges.speaker: Rachel

synsets.definition: inhabit or live in; be an inhabitant of
_examples: People lived in Africa millions of years ago
The people inhabited the islands that are now deserted
this kind of fish dwells near the bottom of the ocean
deer are populating the woods

synsets.definition: lead a certain kind of life; live in a certain style
_examples: we had to live frugally after the war

synsets.definition: continue to live through hardship or adversity
_examples: We went without water and food for 3 days
These superstitions survive in the backwaters of America
The race car driver lived through several very serious accidents
how long can a person last without food and water?

synsets.definition: support oneself
_examples: he could barely exist on such a low wage
Can you live on $2000 a month in New York City?
Many people in the world have to subsist on $1 a day

synsets.definition: have life, be alive
_examples: Our great leader is no more
My grandfather lived until the end of war

synsets.definition: have firsthand knowledge of states, situations, emotions, or sensations
_examples: I know the feeling!
have you ever known hunger?
I have lived a kind of hell when I was a drug addict
The holocaust survivors have lived a nightmare
I lived through two divorces

synsets.definition: pursue a positive and satisfying existence
_examples: You must accept yourself and others if you really want to live

knowledges.origin_sent: Well, I - I could live without it.

knowledges.speaker: Rachel

synsets.definition: come into the possession of something concrete or abstract
_examples: She got a lot of paintings from her uncle
They acquired a new pet
Get your results the next day
Get permission to take a few days off from work

synsets.definition: enter or assume a certain state or condition
_examples: He became annoyed when he heard the bad news
It must be getting more serious
her face went red with anger
She went into ecstasy
Get going!

synsets.definition: cause to move; cause to be in a certain position or condition
_examples: He got his squad on the ball
This let me in for a big surprise
He got a girl into trouble

synsets.definition: receive a specified treatment (abstract)
_examples: These aspects of civilization do not find expression or receive an interpretation
His movie received a good review
I got nothing but trouble for my good intentions

synsets.definition: reach a destination; arrive by movement or progress
_examples: She arrived home at 7 o'clock
She didn't get to Chicago until after midnight

synsets.definition: go or come after and bring or take back
_examples: Get me those books over there, please
Could you bring the wine?
The dog fetched the hat

synsets.definition: go through (mental or physical states or experiences)
_examples: get an idea
experience vertigo
get nauseous
receive injuries
have a feeling

synsets.definition: take vengeance on or get even
_examples: We'll get them!
That'll fix him good!
This time I got him

synsets.definition: achieve a point or goal
_examples: Nicklaus had a 70
The Brazilian team got 4 goals
She made 29 points that day

synsets.definition: cause to do; cause to act in a specified manner
_examples: The ads induced me to buy a VCR
My children finally got me to buy a computer
My wife made me buy a new sofa

synsets.definition: succeed in catching or seizing, especially after a chase
_examples: We finally got the suspect
Did you catch the thief?

synsets.definition: come to have or undergo a change of (physical features and attributes)
_examples: He grew a beard
The patient developed abdominal pains
I got funny spots all over my body
Well-developed breasts

synsets.definition: be stricken by an illness, fall victim to an illness
_examples: He got AIDS
She came down with pneumonia
She took a chill

synsets.definition: communicate with a place or person; establish communication with, as if by telephone
_examples: Bill called this number and he got Mary
The operator couldn't get Kobe because of the earthquake

synsets.definition: give certain properties to something
_examples: get someone mad
She made us look silly
He made a fool of himself at the meeting
Don't make this into a big deal
This invention will make you a millionaire
Make yourself clear

synsets.definition: move into a desired direction of discourse
_examples: What are you driving at?

synsets.definition: grasp with the mind or develop an understanding of
_examples: did you catch that allusion?
We caught something of his theory in the lecture
don't catch your meaning
did you get it?
She didn't get the joke
I just don't get him

synsets.definition: attract and fix
_examples: His look caught her
She caught his eye
Catch the attention of the waiter

synsets.definition: reach with a blow or hit in a particular spot
_examples: the rock caught her in the back of the head
The blow got him in the back
The punch caught him in the stomach

synsets.definition: reach by calculation
_examples: What do you get when you add up these numbers?

synsets.definition: acquire as a result of some effort or action
_examples: You cannot get water out of a stone
Where did she get these news?

synsets.definition: purchase
_examples: What did you get at the toy store?

synsets.definition: perceive by hearing
_examples: I didn't catch your name
She didn't get his name when they met the first time

synsets.definition: suffer from the receipt of
_examples: She will catch hell for this behavior!

synsets.definition: receive as a retribution or punishment
_examples: He got 5 years in prison

synsets.definition: leave immediately; used usually in the imperative form
_examples: Scram!

synsets.definition: reach and board
_examples: She got the bus just as it was leaving

synsets.definition: irritate
_examples: Her childish behavior really get to me
His lying really gets me

synsets.definition: evoke an emotional response
_examples: Brahms's `Requiem' gets me every time

synsets.definition: apprehend and reproduce accurately
_examples: She really caught the spirit of the place in her drawings
She got the mood just right in her photographs

synsets.definition: earn or achieve a base by being walked by the pitcher
_examples: He drew a base on balls

synsets.definition: overcome or destroy
_examples: The ice storm got my hibiscus
the cat got the goldfish

synsets.definition: be a mystery or bewildering to
_examples: This beats me!
Got me--I don't know the answer!
a vexing problem
This question really stuck me

synsets.definition: take the first step or steps in carrying out an action
_examples: We began working at dawn
Who will start?
Get working as soon as the sun rises!
The first tourists began to arrive in Cambodia
He began early in the day
Let's get down to work now

synsets.definition: undergo (as of injuries and illnesses)
_examples: She suffered a fracture in the accident
He had an insulin shock after eating three candy bars
She got a bruise on her leg
He got his arm broken in the scuffle

synsets.definition: make children
_examples: Abraham begot Isaac
Men often father children but don't recognize them

knowledges.origin_sent: I should really get back to work.
